description: in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool 2013 AK Nayak, Mohammad Shahid, R Raja, B Lal, Priyanka Gautam, P Bhattacharyya, Anjani Kumar, R Tripathi, Sangita Mohanty, BB Panda, SD Mohapatra, KM Das and AK Shukla
Cuttack 753006, Odisha, India

crop_name: Rice is a major cereal crop grown across the world and meets the food
description: demand of more than half of the world population. There is a wide varia- tion in rice yield from one region to other more so in India. For improving and sustaining the rice yield to meet the demand of burgeoning popula- tion, there is a need to apply all the ingenuity of rice science. Managing the nutrient deficiencies, toxicities and pathogenic diseases is key to achieve this goal. A simple and easy to use visual diagnostic tool is very effective for timely identifying the symptoms and applying the corrective measures at field level. Normally 16 elements are considered as essential, out of which N, P and K are the primary macronutrients; Ca, Mg and S are the secondary macronutrients; and Fe, Mn, Zn, Cu, B, Mo and Cl are the micronutri- ents. For optimum growth and reproduction all the essential nutrients are required by plants in balanced proportion. Nutrient deficiency occurs when an essential nutrient is not available in sufficient quantity to meet the requirements of a growing plant while the toxicity occurs when a nutrient is in excess of critical limits of plant. Both the situation hamper the nor- mal plant growth and exhibit characteristics symptoms.

crop_name: Plant diseases also show visible symptoms like nutrient deficiency and
description: toxicity symptoms, sometimes it is difficult to distinguish one from an- other and requires expertise on the visual diagnosis. Though laboratory based molecular techniques are accurate tools, the visible symptoms based on the morphological characters sometimes are the only means of diagno- sis available to farmers for adopting the corrective measures against the pathogenic diseases. In most of the cases, interpreting visual nutrient deficiency, toxicity and disease symptoms in plants can be difficult, even for the most experi- enced eyes and hence plant analysis or soil testing is necessary to confirm the result. Many symptoms appear similar and multiple deficiencies and/ or toxicities can occur at the same time, making it even more confusing. Nutrient deficiencies can also be confused with symptoms of disease, drought, excess water, herbicide and pesticide damage and pest attack. This book on visual symptoms of nutrient deficiency, toxicity and some major disease in rice crop is designed as a management guide to identify, understand and manage the occurrence of nutrient deficiencies, toxicities and diseases in rice crop. We hope that this book will act as an useful tool for rice researchers, extension workers, students and farmers, and would help to boost up the rice production and productivity.
Soil Science & Microbiology Soil Science & Microbiology

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool

Plants need 16 elements for their growth and completion of life cycle. Plant takes C from atmosphere, H and O from water and rest 13 (N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S, Fe, Mn, Zn, Cu, B, Mo and Cl) are mainly absorbed from soil. These elements are essential for rice plant in one form or other for per- forming various metabolic functions and to complete vegetative and re- productive stages of life cycle (Table 1). There are also some beneficial elements like Ni, Na, Si and Co. Plant growth is af- fected when any of the essential nutrient is not present in soil in opti- mum range. Plants may not show visual symptoms up to a cer- tain level of nutrient content, but growth is affected and this situ- ation is known as hid- den hunger. When a nutrient level still falls, plants show character- Fig 1. Concentration of essential elements istics symptoms of de- exhibiting deficiency or toxicity ficiency (Fig. 1). When present in excess, it shows symptoms of toxicity. Growth and/or quality of plants are affected in both the situations. Nutri- ent deficiency and toxicity are often referred as nutrient disorders.

crop_name: Some symptoms are masked by diseases and other stresses therefore a
description: careful and patient observation is required on more number of plants for typical symptoms of nutrient disorders.

crop_name: A number of integrated factors which influence nutrient availability to
description: plants resulting in nutritional disorders. The deficiency and toxicity of macro and micronutrients in soil may arise due to: i) natural supply of nutrients; ii) adverse soil conditions such as excessive acidity, alkalinity and salinity; iii) relative activity of micro-organisms which play a vital role in nutrient release; iv) addition of fertilizer; v) weather conditions. Severe deficiencies (in some cases hidden hunger) and toxicities can be identified by visual symptoms, clearly examining and differentiating from disease symptoms. 1(cid:132)

Nitrogen (N) It is integral part of chlorophyll. It promotes rapid growth, increase plant height and tiller number. It plays an impor tant role in synthesis of proteins, enzymes, hormones, vita mins, alkaloids, nucleic acids (DNA, RNA) etc. Phosphorus (P) It plays central role in energy transfer and protein metabo- lism. It is a constituent of sugar phosphates, nucleotides, nucleic acids, co-enzymes and phospho-lipids. Potassium (K) It helps in osmotic and ionic regulation and is required as a co-factor or activator for 40 or more enzymes. It imparts disease and drought resistance. Calcium (Ca) It is involved in cell division and plays a major role in the maintenance of membrane integrity. It is a constituent of cell wall as calcium pectate. Magnesium (Mg) It is central part of chlorophyll and it is required in several enzymes involved in phosphate transfer. It is structural com- ponent of ribosomes. Sulfur (S) Somewhat like phosphorus, it is involved in plant cell en- ergetics. It plays an important role in plant lipid synthesis and amino acids. Zinc (Zn) It is an essential component of several enzyme systems (de- hydrogenases, proteinases and peptidases including carbonic anhydrase and alcohol dehydrogenase). Iron (Fe) As a constituent of various enzymes (cytochrome, catalase, dipeptides etc.), iron plays the part of a vital catalyst in the plant. It is a key element in various redox reaction of respi- ration and photosynthesis. Manganese (Mn) It is involved in the O evolving system of photosynthesis 2 and it is a constituent of decarboxylases, kinases, oxidases etc. and hence, essential for respiration, formation of chlo- rophyll and reduction in nitrates. Copper (Cu) Acting as a component of metalloenzymes, regulating some enzymatic actions, and catalyzing oxidation reactions; Play ing a role in: i) nitrogen, protein and hormone metabolism; ii) photosynthesis and respiration. Contd..... (cid:132)2

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool

Boron (B) It is essential for development and growth of new cells in plant meristem. It is necessary for the germination of pol- len, formation of flowers and for the absorption of cations. Molybdenum (Mo) It’s function in rice plants is limited to the reduction of nitrate to nitrite. It is a component of nitrogenase, nitrate reductase, sulphate oxidase and xanthine hydrogenase en- zymes . Chlorine (Cl) Essential for photosynthesis and as an activator of enzymes involved in splitting of water. Associated with osmo-regula- tion of plants growing in saline soils.

crop_name: Diagnosis of nutrient disorders in rice plants
The cheapest diagnostic technique for identifying nutrient disorders
description: in rice is visual symptoms. There are three steps in identifying nutrient disorders by visual symptoms. 1. Observing plants for its normal growth and development Symptoms are one way plants communicate; they are a kind of lan- guage. When plants are deficient in a nutrient or suffer toxicity of an element visible symptoms appear. Plant height: Stunted growth is a common symptom for deficiency or toxicity, but N and P have more influence on growth reduction. Unusually tall plants may be induced by Bakanae disease. Tillers: Reduced tiller number is a common symptom for deficiency or toxicity. Leaves: Chlorosis, necrosis (brown spots) and orange discoloration are common symptoms of deficiency or toxicity. 2. Identifying the affected plant parts

crop_name: The mobility of nutrients within the plant and the position of the leaf
description: on which the deficiency symptoms appear are interrelated. Knowledge of mobility of nutrients in the plant helps in finding which nutrient is defi- cient. A mobile nutrient in the plant moves to the growing points in case of deficiency, therefore symptoms appear on the lower leaves. For a nutri- ent whose mobility is low, symptoms normally appear in upper leaves because the nutrient fails to move from lower to upper leaves where it is needed for active growth (Fig. 2). Based on the mobility in plants nutri- ents are grouped as follows: 3(cid:132)
leaves buds
N , P, K, Mg Ca, B Zn, Mo S, Fe, Mn, Cu

(cid:55) Some hunger signs are common for more than one elements e.g. all the elements which govern the chlorophyll content such as N, Fe, and Mg show similar symptoms. (cid:55) Deficiency and toxicity symptoms of plant nutrients sometimes re- sembles with the symptoms of certain plant diseases. (cid:55) An attack of insect, pest and disease or mechanical injury may cause wilting which may be similar to the symptoms for certain deficient/ toxic elements. crop_name: Plant diseases also show visible symptoms like deficiency and toxicity
description: symptoms, sometimes it is difficult to distinguish one from another and requires expertise on the visual diagnosis. Though laboratory based 5(cid:132)

crop_name: Progression of symptoms is one of the most important characteristics
description: associated with problems caused by biotic agents. In some cases, such as improper herbicide usage, symptoms observed may be similar to spots present as a result of an infectious agent, but with herbicide injury, the symptoms usually appear suddenly and there is no observable progression of symptoms. The spots may also follow spray patterns of the herbicide. Herbicides, such as 2,4-D, can cause leaf distortion which may be con- fused with viral diseases. However, when new leaves form, they will gen- erally be free of symptoms, indicating a lack of symptom progression. Similarly, deficiency and toxicity symptoms may also resemble with the symptoms caused by diseases. The difference is that most of the plant diseases appear under favorable weather conditions like high humidity, day and night temperature, cloudiness etc. and occurs mostly in patches except under severe infestation. However, the symptoms of nutrient defi- ciencies and toxicities generally spread uniformly in the field. Signs of plant diseases are the observable evidence of the actual dis- ease causing agent. Signs are much more specific to disease causing agents than are symptoms and are extremely useful in the proper diagnosis of a disease and identification of the agent causing the disease. The use of a magnifying lens and a knife can be valuable for a diagnostician in the field. For example, bacterial ooze can be observed by cutting the affected stems and placing them in water.

crop_name: Variations in symptoms expressed by diseased plants may lead to an
description: improper diagnosis. It is possible that more than one problem may present.

crop_name: Sometimes symptoms associated with deficiencies and toxicities appear
Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool simultaneously with the disease symptoms as the nutrient deficiency and toxicity is the predisposed condition for the occurrence of some diseases.

crop_name: Interaction between nutrient and plant diseases
description: Interactions between plants, nutrients, and disease pathogens are very complex and not completely understood. Nutrition, although frequently unrecognized, has always been a primary component of disease control. Plants suffering a nutrient stress will be less vigorous and more suscep- tible to a variety of diseases. The severity of most diseases can be reduced and the chemical, biological or genetic control of many plant pathogens can be enhanced by proper nutrition (Table 2). Table 2. Plant diseases and nutrient interactions

crop_name: Nitrogen Excessive N enhanced tissue susceptibility to blast disease N
description: suppresses fungal disease and feeding intensity of sucking insects.

crop_name: Phosphorus P lowers the susceptibility to fungal attacks because it is a com
description: ponent of phospholipids in cellular membranes.

crop_name: Potassium K application reduces insect attacks and fungal and nematode
description: infections, because is has a role in cellular functions and thick- cuticle development. Calcium Ca as a component of calcium pectate in the middle lamella, its levels were related to lower susceptibility of leaves to fungus.

crop_name: Sulphur S used as fungicide to control and suppress fungal diseases
description: Accumulation of S in xylem vessel invading fungal pathogen. Zinc Zn prevents leakage of sugar onto the plant surfaces, which can enhance the invasion of fungus and bacteria.

crop_name: Copper Cu fertilization decreases the severity of the Pyricularia oryzae
description: on rice due to its role as a component of polyphenol oxidase

crop_name: Copper has the ability to denature the spores and conidia of
description: fungus. Silicon Diseases such as blast, brown spot and sheath blight can be ex- tremely threatening to rice cultivation if Si is deficient in soil. Silicon has physiological roles in disease resistance. 7(cid:132)

crop_name: Essential nutrient elements besides their growth enhancing and yield
description: maximizing roles may also have secondary effect on survival and viru- lence of pathogens or the tolerance of the host plant to the disease. Defi- ciency of nutrients has often been regarded as predisposing factors in plant susceptibility to many plant diseases. Application of nutrient elements has shown reduction in disease incidence in rice plant (Table 3). Table 3. Disease incidence reduction vis-à-vis plant nutrients

Leaf spot Alternaria spp.

description: deficiencies, toxicities and diseases whose symptoms resembles with the deficiency symptoms or excess of nutrients in rice plant have been pre- sented which can serve as a guide to diagnose and take timely, appropri- ate remedial measures so that productivity can be enhanced. (cid:55) Alkaline and sodic soil with low organic matter in soil (cid:55) Leached and acid sulphate soils (cid:55) Degraded soils containing large amount of soluble iron (cid:55) Excessive liming of acid soils

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool 3. Mineral Toxicity

(cid:55) Symptoms first appear in old leaves and is characterized by a reddish brown, yellow, or purple bronzing or orange discoloration of the leaves (cid:55) Tiny brown spots start at leaf tips and spread towards the base and then coalesce on the interveins (cid:55) In severe stress, the entire affected leaves look purplish brown (cid:55) The roots become dark brown in color (cid:55) Symptoms commonly develop at the maximum tillering and heading stage (cid:55) A red brown oily scum on the surface of stagnant water (cid:55) Deficiency symptoms of other elements such as P, K, Ca, Mn and Zn may appear

(cid:55) Fe-toxicity occurs mostly in Ultisols, Oxisols and acid sulfate soils, high in active iron and potential acidity, irrespective of organic matter and texture (cid:55) Light textured acid soils in valleys receiving interflow water from ad- jacent higher land rich in iron (cid:55) Water logged soils with poor drainage (cid:55) High water table and poor nutrient status of soil may cause Fe-toxicity under certain situation

crop_name: Growth stage Plant part Optimum range Critical level for
description: (mg kg-1) toxicity (mg kg-1) Tillering to PI Y-leaf* 75-150 > 300-500 * Uppermost fully expanded leaf

(cid:55) Drain the soil to oxidize reduced ferrous ions (Fe2+) (cid:55) Liming acid soils may also reduce Fe-toxicity (cid:55) Apply additional K, Mn and Zn (cid:55) Plant tolerant cultivars/genotypes (cid:55) Delay the planting till the peak in Fe2+ concentration has passed (cid:55) Carry out dry tillage after the rice harvest to increase Fe2+ oxidation during the fallow period (cid:132)32

(cid:55) Appearance of a light brown or yellowish white discoloration on the tips and margins of the older leaves (cid:55) With the progress of toxicity, leaf tips eventually turn brown and die (cid:55) Later on, elliptical dark brown blotches appear in the discolored areas (cid:55) Finally the entire leaf blade turns light brown and withers (cid:55) Symptoms appear during early tillering
(cid:55) Arid irrigated areas, in saline, sodic soils and in volcanic areas (cid:55) Use of irrigation water with high B content (> 2 ppm)

(cid:55) Plant B toxicity tolerant varieties (cid:55) Use irrigation water with low B content (cid:55) If B concentration is very high in irrigation water, dilute it with good quality water before use (cid:55) To reduce the level of boron in the soil solution, use irrigation water with low boron content to leach boron form the root zone (cid:55) Avoid over use of urban compost/sewage water (cid:132)34

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool 3.5 SULPHIDE TOXICITY

(cid:55) Interveinal chlorosis of emerging leaves similar to that of Fe defi- ciency, older leaves become yellow and dry out prematurely (cid:55) Parched appearance of field and poorly developed root system (cid:55) The roots appear black when pulled out of the soil and turn to reddish brown when exposed to air (cid:55) The roots and the rhizospheric soil emit foul smell of hydrogen sul- phide (cid:55) Hydrogen sulphide toxicity of rice is known as “Akiochi disease”, causes black crown and root rot in rice
(cid:55) Soils having highly reduced condition (cid:55) Poorly drained organic soils (cid:55) Acid sulphate soils (cid:55) Soil containing large concentration of hydrogen sulphide

description: sulphide injury 39(cid:132) sasnakrA fo ytisrevinU :otohP sasnakrA fo ytisrevinU :otohP

(cid:55) Proper drainage is necessary (cid:55) Dry tillage after harvesting the crop decreases the redox potential (cid:55) Application of Si with balanced application of fertilizer (cid:55) Avoid excessive use of organic residues

(cid:55) Water soaked lesions move from tip to downwards on the edges of leaves (cid:55) Gradually, symptoms turn into yellow and straw coloured stripes with wavy margins (cid:55) In Kresek (wilt) phase, leaves roll completely, droop and plants die completely (cid:55) Late season potassium deficiency resembles to BLB. However, in case of BLB, a yellowish, opaque, turbid drops of bacterial ooze will come out from cut edge of the infected leaf when immersed in water (Ooze test). (cid:55) In the early stage of the disease, it is difficult to distinguish BLB and bacterial leaf streak. In case of BLB, the symptoms start appearing from the tip and progress downwards in the form of inverted ‘V’ shape. (cid:55) Affected grains have discoloured spots sorrounded by water soaked areas

(cid:55) Grow tolerant varieties such as IR 64, Ajaya, Naveen, Lalat, Gayatri, Varsadhan, Sarjoo 52, Saket (cid:55) Treat the seed by soaking 1 kg seeds in 2 liters of water containing 0.15 g streptocycline + 2 g captan for 8-10 hours (cid:55) Soak the seed for 12 hrs and treat in hot water at 53°C for 30 min (cid:55) Dip roots of the seedlings in solution of plantomycin (0.1%) or streptocycline (0.01%) for 30 minutes (cid:55) Balanced fertilizer application with split application of N (cid:55) Potash application, alternate drying and flooding in the field help in reducing infection (cid:55) Give need based spray of plantomycin @ 1 g L-1 of water or streptocycline (0.15g) + copper oxy chloride (1 g) per liter of water (cid:55) Spray fresh cow dung extracts (1 kg cow dung in 5 liter water) (cid:132)42

description: on the sides of the leaves starting from tip Inverted ‘V’ shape symptom in BLB infected rice leaf Late season potassium deficiency resembling BLB 43(cid:132) eciR anaisiuoL :otohP

(cid:55) Spots appear in the leaves and glumes of the affected plants, some- times seedlings, sheaths, stems and grains may also show the symp- tom (cid:55) Infected seedlings have small, circular or oval, brown lesions. In se- vere infestation seedlings become stunted or die (cid:55) On older leaves, small, circular, dark brown or purplish brown young or underdeveloped lesions appear. A fully developed lesion on older leaves is oval, brown with gray or whitish center with reddish brown margin (cid:55) Under severe infection, the lesions may coalesce, killing large areas of affected leaves (cid:55) Black or dark lesions with a velvety aspect also develop on glumes (cid:55) Black discoloration or brown lesions appear on grains of infected plants (cid:55) In some cases, the fungus may also infect and cause a black discolora- tion of the roots (cid:55) In potassium deficient plants brown spot appears in the older leaves sometimes create confusion in diagnosis. However, in the former case the spots are dusky without any distinct margin.

(cid:55) Use healthy seeds from disease free crops (cid:55) Adopt deep summer ploughing (cid:55) Apply balanced NPK with zinc and manganese (if soil is deficit in Mn) (cid:55) Apply addtional K (20% extra) at the appearance of disease (cid:55) Grow tolerant varieties such as Naveen, Komal-9, Savitri, Parijat
(cid:55) Treat the seeds with captan or thiram (3 g kg-1 seed) (cid:55) Spray with propiconazole @ 1 mL L-1 or 0.4% mancozeb or 0.25% ziram or 0.2% carbendazim (cid:132)44

description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool Small, circular, dark brown lesions Severely infected plant showing oval, brown spot on leaves with gray/ whitish center with reddish brown margin

crop_name: Late season K deficiency with irregular spots concentrated
description: towards leaf tip

crop_name: Brown spot along with the symptoms of K deficiency

description: (cid:55) Disease occurs at all the crop stages viz., nursery, tillering and flowering (cid:55) On the leaves, elliptical or spindle shaped lesions with brown border and grayish/ashy center occur (Leaf blast) (cid:55) Under favorable conditions, these lesions enlarge and coalesce and entire leaf withers (cid:55) The pathogen also infects the collar region marked by rusty brown appearance at the junction of leaf blade and leaf sheath and ulti- mately entire leaf blade dries up (Collar blast) (cid:55) The disease affected stems turn dark brown to blackish colour at the node. The stem becomes weak and break easily (Node blast). (cid:55) Black necrotic lesions around the base of the panicles may occur re- sulting in breakdown of panicles and formation of chaffy grains (Neck blast) (cid:55) Usually, the symptoms appear in the soils rich in N/fields applied with excess N

(cid:55) Use healthy seeds collected from disease free crops (cid:55) Apply balanced dose of nitrogenous fertilizer in 3-4 splits (80 kg N ha-1) (cid:55) Weed out alternate hosts viz; Cynodron sp. and Paspalum sp. (cid:55) Maintain standing water in the field (cid:55) Grow tolerant varieties such as Heera, Vandana, Kalinga III, Annada, IR 64, Gayatri (cid:55) Give need based spray of some effective fungicides or plant products- carbendazim 50WP (2 g L-1 water) of water or tricyclazole 75WP (0.6g L-1 water) of water or Bael leaf extract (25 g fresh leaves L-1 water) or Tulsi leaf extract (25 g fresh young leaves L-1 water) or Neem leaf extract (200 g fresh leaves L-1 water) (cid:132)46

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool

crop_name: Spindle shaped lesions on the leaves with Collar blast
description: brown border and grayish centre

(cid:55) The symptoms usually appear as small, dark-green and water-soaked streaks between the veins from tillering to booting stage (cid:55) The streaks appear dark-green in the beginning, enlarge later to be- come yellowish gray and translucent then turn to light brown or yel- lowish brown (cid:55) Large areas of the leaf may become dry due to numerous streaks. At the later stage, the disease is indistinguishable from the BLB however, the later can be distinguished by its ‘inverted V’ shape appearance. (cid:55) Sometimes potassium deficiency can be confused with BLS, however potassium deficiency symptom starts from the leaf tip and margin and progresses toward mid rib (cid:55) Bacterial exudates from the infected cut leaves when placed in water confirms the infection

(cid:55) Treat the seeds by soaking 1 kg seeds in 2 liters of water containing 0.15 g streptocycline + 2 g captan for 8-10 hours (cid:55) Hot water treatment of seeds for 12 hours at 530C for 30 minutes (cid:55) Root dipping of seedlings in plantomycin (0.1%) or streptocycline (0.01%) for 30 minutes (cid:55) Grow tolerant varieties such as Gayatri, Durga, Varshadhan, Rambha,

(cid:55) Apply balanced dose of NPK (cid:55) Additional potash application in the field helps in reducing infection (cid:55) Avoid field to field irrigation (cid:55) Avoid clipping of seedlings at the time of transplanting (cid:55) Upon on set of symptoms, spray plantomycin 1 g + copperoxychloride 1 g L-1 twice at an interval of 8 days (cid:55) Spray fresh cow dung extract (1 kg cow dung in 5 liters water) thrice at eight days interval (cid:132)48

crop_name: Identification and Management of Nutrient Disorders and
description: Diseases in Rice: A Visual Diagnostic Tool
interveinal streaks on early infected leaf 49(cid:132)

(cid:55) Sheath blight disease usually appears in the later growth stages of the plant in the late tillering or early internode elongation stage (cid:55) Initial symptoms appear on sheaths of lower leaves or just below the leaf collar near the water line and is characterized by small, ellipsoi- dal or ovoid, greenish-gray and water-soaked lesions (cid:55) Later on the lesions occur with a grayish white center and light brown to dark brown margin (cid:55) Disease development progresses very rapidly in the early heading and grain filling stages and may reach the uppermost leaf under favorable conditions (cid:55) During later stage of disease, lesions will dry and become grayish- white to tan with brownish borders and may coalesce forming bigger lesions with irregular outline and may cause the death of the whole leaf (cid:55) Severely infected plants produced poorly filled or empty grains, espe- cially those on the lower portion of the panicles (cid:55) At times white sclerotia of mustard seed size found on infected sheaths

(cid:55) Adopt deep summer ploughing so that sclerotia remaining inside the soil are exposed to hot sunlight (cid:55) Incorporate green manure (Sesbania sp.) in sheath blight endemic areas (cid:55) Do not transplant more than 3 seedlings hill-1 (cid:55) Maintain field sanitation by removing weeds (cid:55) Grow sheath blight tolerant varieties such as Ajaya, IR 36, Ratna, CR 1014, Nalini (cid:55) Need based spray of effective fungicides- validamycin 3L (2 mL L-1 water)or hexaconazole 5 EC (2 mL L-1 water) or thifluzamide 24SC (1 mL L-1 water) or carbendazim 50 WP (2.5 g L-1 water) (cid:132)50

(cid:55) Freshly emerged leaves exhibit intervenial chlorosis (cid:55) Leaves gradually turn pale yellow and later reddish orange in colour (cid:55) Plants get stunted and numbers of tillers are reduced (cid:55) At the maturity stage, panicles do not exert completely (cid:55) Tungro infected plants show impaired root growth (cid:55) Symptoms of K deficiency are similar to those of tungro virus disease (cid:55) Unlike K deficiency, however, tungro occurs as patches within a field, affecting single hills rather than the whole field

(cid:55) Avoid late planting (beyond 2nd week of August) in Eastern Indian states (cid:55) Clean out weeds like C. rotundus, H. compressa, Hydrolia Zeylanica and Phyllanthus niruri from surrounding of the rice fields (cid:55) Need based application of cartap hydrochloride 4G @ 25 kg ha-1 or carbofuran @ 25 kg ha-1 (cid:55) Give need based spray of imidacloprid 200SL @ 0.5 mL L-1 of water (cid:55) Grow tolerant varieties such as Ratna, Naveen, Lunishree etc. (cid:132)52
